tossups.question: This essay argues that the Tory party “long imagined” it was “enthusiastic about the monarchy, the church, and the old English constitution,” until “the day of danger” revealed its only enthusiasm was “ground rent.” This essay describes a transformation that resulted in Locke “supplanting” Habbakuk. This essay describes how landlords and industrialists formed antagonistic wings of the “Party of Order,” paving the way for a (*) “grotesque mediocrity.” First published in 1852, this essay observes “men make their own history, but they do not make it as they please.” It interprets the Revolution of 1848 as a parody of the French Revolution, claiming that all “great world-historic facts and personages” appear twice, “The first time as tragedy, the second as farce.” For 10 points, name this essay by Karl Marx about a coup performed by the title French monarch.
tossups.answer: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Napoleon [or The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte; or Der 18te Brumaire des Louis Napoleon] <Mythology and Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Napoleon [or The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte; or Der 18te Brumaire des Louis Napoleon]
acceptable: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Napoleon
The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte

tossups.question: Up to 70% of T-cell ALLs have a gain of function mutation in a gene in this pathway essential for T-cell development. The neuronal migration glycoprotein reelin [reel-in] signals via this pathway. An arteri·opathy of the brain causing mini-strokes and damage to the white matter is due to germline mutations in a protein in this pathway; that disease is CADASIL. GLP-1, a homolog to the central protein in this pathway, acts as a membrane receptor for the distal tip signal. Fringe glycosyl·transferases act on the E·G·F repeats of the protein central to this pathway, which is cleaved by ADAM10 and gamma-secretase after ligands bind to it. In humans, (*) delta-like-ligand 4 inhibitors target a component of this pathway to prevent angiogenesis in tumors. Poulson showed that dysfunction of this pathway led to an embryonic lethal phenotype in Drosophila. For 10 points, partial loss of function in what pathway leads to the formation of dents on the wings of flies?
tossups.answer: Notch signaling pathway <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: The longtime dictator of this nation enjoyed carrying around bullets from numerous assassination attempts, including one by his own bodyguard, who found him too insufferable to live. U.S. ambassador Leon Poullada had a very bad morning in this country in 1963, when he opened the door to find the bullet-riddled body of its first president lying on the front step. A dictator in this country supposedly held an annual “Feast of Victory over the Forces of Evil” to commemorate being the sole survivor of a plane crash supposedly orchestrated after he tried to nationalize this country’s rich phosphate industries. Negotiations with Mlapa III led the area comprising this modern-day country to be the first location on the African continent where (*) Germany raised its flag. Strife between this country and its western neighbor began when this country’s president Sylvanus Olympio called Kwame Nkrumah “a black imperialist.” Long led by Gnassingbe Eyadema—for 10 points—name this West African country sandwiched between Ghana and Benin, with capital at Lome.
tossups.answer: Togo [or Togolese Republic or République togolaise] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: A poem named for this man claims that “The spouting head spiked as prophetic is ancient news.” That five-part poem named for this man’s funeral appears in Geoffrey Hill’s collection Canaan. This author described how he began painting in the essay “Painting as a Pastime,” which was published in his book Thoughts and Adventures. Kurt Steiner orchestrates an attempt to kidnap this man in Jack Higgins’ novel The (*) Eagle Has Landed. At the climax of Joe Orton’s play What the Butler Saw, Sergeant Match triumphantly brandishes a bronze replica of this man’s penis. Rebecca Hunt’s novel Mr. Chartwell literalizes this author’s description of his depression as his “black dog.” This man included volumes called “The Great Democracies” and “The Birth of Britain” in his last book, A History of the English-Speaking Peoples. For 10 points, name this author who delivered speeches like “This was their finest hour.”
tossups.answer: Winston (Leonard Spencer-)Churchill <Literature - British>

tossups.question: U.S. military theorist Arthur Wagner titled a tactical treatise for this battle, where he claimed that the losing side’s artillery relied too heavily on rocket batteries, the last time such weapons were used in a major European engagement. A traditional drum wagon in the winner’s army honors Sultan, a Saint Bernard mascot who was gunned down at this battle. After urging peace talks, the losing commander at this battle seems to have tragically misunderstood his monarch’s telegram reply of “has a battle taken place?” to be a savage dig at his cowardice. A contentious stand-off in this battle took place in the (*) Swieb forest where one side was unable to support their troops with volleys from Masloved hill over fears of friendly fire. Franz Joseph I was forced to sign the Peace of Prague after this battle, which saw Ludwig von Benedek’s muzzle-loading Lorenz rifle outclassed by the breech-loading Dreyse needle gun used by forces under von Moltke the Elder. For 10 points, name this 1866 battle that ended the Austro-Prussian War.
tossups.answer: Battle of Königgrätz [accept Battle of Sadowa [sah-do-va]] <History - European>

tossups.question: The proteasome inhibitor MG-132 has this functionality. K.C. Nicolau closed ring B of taxol in his namesake total synthesis by coupling two of this functionality using a zinc-copper couple and titanium trichloride in glyme solvent. Reacting a highly activated aromatic ring with hexamine in the presence of acetic acid followed by sulfuric acid generates this functionality in a reaction named for Duff. Reacting E-enolates with (*) alpha-chiral examples of these molecules will give the anti-Felkin product. They are formed by reacting an arene with DMF and phosphorous oxychloride in the Vilsmeier–Haack reaction. Reacting acyl chlorides with a methylated hydroxylamine produces a Weinreb amide, which is treated with lithium aluminum hydride to form these compounds. The treatment of esters with DIBAL-H yields this functionality, which can also be formed via the Swern oxidation of primary alcohols. For 10 points each, name these electrophilic compounds with a terminal carbonyl group.
tossups.answer: aldehydes [accept formyl; prompt on carbonyl compounds] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: Using data from South Africa, Michael Carter and Julian May separated this phenomenon into “structural” and “stochastic” forms. A paper by Mary Jo Bane and Doug Ellwood analyzed the dynamics of this phenomenon through the categories of “spells” and “exit probabilities.” The “Micawber threshold” is one explanation for the continued existence of this phenomenon. Martin (*) Ravallion’s original metric for measuring this phenomenon around the world was updated in 2015. The Foster–Greer–Thorbecke indices measure inequality that occurs within this phenomenon, as opposed to the “headcount ratio.” One book argues that the “identification” of this phenomenon must occur before the “aggregation” of its characteristics. That book, which uses the “entitlement approach” to analyze this phenomenon’s connection to famines, is by Amartya Sen. For 10 points, name this condition of being unable to meet all basic needs due to a lack of income.
tossups.answer: poverty [accept word forms; prompt on starvation or famines] <Social Science>
tossups.answer_formatted: poverty [ accept word forms; prompt on starvation or famines]

tossups.question: This was the second in a set of three syllables used to solmize the pitch “A,” which a Renaissance copyist named Petrus took as his pseudonym. The cantus firmus begins on the note of the natural hexachord denoted by this syllable in the Credo of Josquin’s Missa L’homme armé super voces musicales. Since its bass part begins by descending from one note solmized with this syllable to another, this syllable is repeated twice in the nickname of a mass by Johannes Ockeghem. The nickname “Diabolus in Musica” for the tritone came from a rhyme that warns against putting “[this syllable] contra [the syllable after it].” Before the seventh syllable (*) “ti” or “si” was added, this syllable was used for the note “B.” This syllable was used to solmize all notes with a sharp since it’s a half-step lower than its neighbor; thus, in movable-do, this syllable’s vowel is given to any raised pitch. In fixed-do, this is the syllable for the pitch “E.” For 10 points, name this third solfège syllable, which comes after “re.”
tossups.answer: mi [accept Petrus Alamire; accept Missa Mi-Mi; accept “mi contra fa”] <Arts - Auditory>
tossups.answer_formatted: mi [accept Petrus Alamire; accept Missa Mi-Mi; accept “mi contra fa”]

tossups.question: This work inspired and partially titles a 1969 paper by Ruth Finnegan which presents a study of the Limba people of Sierra Leone. Another book’s epigraph attacks a footnote in this book remarking that we are “still confining ourselves, for simplicity.” This book concludes that “the algebra of marriage is Boolean” when discussing the ambuigity of the phrase “commiting bigamy,” since a bigamous person does not marry twice. This book uses the examples of (*) betting sixpence that it is raining and of naming a ship the Queen Elizabeth to illustrate sentences that have no true-false values. This book distinguishes between acts “purported but void” and those “professed but hollow” as “misfires” and “abuses,” two types of infelicities possible in a “verbal formula.” For 10 points, “speech acts” or “performative utterances” are discussed in what collection of lectures by J.L. Austin?
tossups.answer: How To Do Things With Words <Philosophy>
acceptable: How To Do Things With Words <Philosophy>

tossups.question: A poem by this author compares the number of people “wise in hindsight” and “wise in foresight” before concluding that “one hundred out of one hundred” are mortal. This poet of “A Word on Statistics” described a “‘sorry’ muttered in a crowd” and “a curt ‘wrong number’ caught in the receiver” in a poem that ends by stating that “the book of events is always open halfway through.” The speaker stomps her “feet for warmth on the everlasting (*) snow” at the end of a poem by this author, who wrote about an object that “does just fine, without a name” in the title poem of a 1995 collection. This poet of “Notes from a Nonexistent Himalayan Expedition” included “Love at First Sight” in her collection The End and the Beginning. For 10 points, name this author of the collections Calling Out to Yeti and View with a Grain of Sand, a Polish poet who won the 1996 Nobel Prize in Literature.
tossups.answer: Wisława Szymborska [or Maria Wisława Anna Szymborska-Włodek] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: The first black-owned film studio was founded by actor Noble Johnson in this state and named for its capital city. A long-serving black legislator in this state is a militant atheist whose attempt to de-fund Congressional chaplains led to the case Marsh v. Chambers. Several women of the LaFlesche family, including the first Native American to earn a medical degree, were prominent Indian rights activists in this state. The first legal recognition of native rights emerged from a case brought against George Crook by a Ponca chief from this state, (*) Standing Bear. At the 1896 Democratic convention, a populist from this state extolled free silver in the “Cross of Gold” speech. It’s not Florida, but the Ocala demands influenced a document produced in this state that led to James Weaver’s candidacy for the Populist party in 1892, the namesake “platform” of its largest city. For 10 points, name this home state of William Jennings Bryan, where the Omaha Platform was written.
tossups.answer: Nebraska <History - American>

tossups.question: Except for mirror supports, all of the parts of this currently-active telescope are made of beryllium. This telescope is separated into “cold” and “warm” portions due to its cryogenic assembly, while its primary mirror is cooled to 5.5 Kelvin by that assembly. MIPS and IRAC [“eye-rack”] are two instruments used on this telescope, which found the Double Helix Nebula near the center of the Milky Way inside a “zone of avoidance.” Operating in the same radiation range as (*) SOFIA, this telescope discovered the largest batch of exoplanets in the TRAPPIST-1 system. In 2005, this telescope became the first to gather light from hot Jupiters. Its namesake pioneered the study of the interstellar medium and was one of the first to suggest launching a telescope out of the atmosphere for clearer resolution. The James Webb Telescope will combine the utility of this telescope with Hubble. For 10 points, name this 2003-launched NASA telescope that is set to retire on January 30th, 2020, which captures infrared light.
tossups.answer: Spitzer Space Telescope <Science - Other>

tossups.question: A box-shaped 1964 painting titled for this figure is over 8 feet tall with a bright red background, against which a Pop Art-style rendition of his figure shoots a machine gun. Joe Overstreet titled that painting for a New version of this figure. Another work titled for this figure uses brown backgrounds for an outer ring of portraits, yellow backgrounds for an inner ring, and dark brown backgrounds for this figure and this figure’s parents. In an artwork titled for this person, a clenched fist is painted onto the postcard in front of a sculpture of this person, who holds a (*) broom and rifle. This woman and her husband Big Rufus open a Harlem restaurant in a story told across 7 of the 56 squares of a 1983 artwork. A Betye Saar piece is titled for the Liberation of this woman. Faith Ringgold’s first story quilt asks Who’s Afraid of—for 10 points—what version of the “mammy” stereotype often used in advertising?
tossups.answer: Aunt Jemima [accept The New Jemima or The Liberation of Aunt Jemima or Who’s Afraid of Aunt Jemima?] <Arts - Visual>
tossups.answer_formatted: Aunt Jemima [accept The New Jemima or The Liberation of Aunt Jemima or Who’s Afraid of Aunt Jemima?]

tossups.question: Azar Nafisi’s book Reading Lolita in Tehran describes how she drew courage during nighttime bombings from this character’s repeated line “You needn’t be afraid.” The protagonist is struck with a “sudden illumination” about how to read the ambiguity of this character’s behavior after seeing her at night with a “clever imitation” of a gentleman. This character’s death leads the protagonist to tell his aunt “I have lived too long in foreign parts.” At a party, she tells the protagonist that she doesn’t want to change her habits, exclaiming “I’m a fearful, frightful (*) flirt!” This character rebuffs Mrs. Walker by refusing to get in her carriage and instead walks towards the Pincio. After meeting her younger brother Randolph, the protagonist takes her to the Château de Chillon in Vevey. For 10 points, name this young American girl from Schenectady who scandalizes members of society like Frederick Winterbourne in a novella by Henry James.
tossups.answer: Daisy Miller [or Daisy Miller; or Annie P. Miller] <Literature - American>

tossups.question: The original version of one of these texts concludes with the unusual phrase “aiónas tón aiónon.” Chant books often abbreviate a phrase from one of these texts using the vowels “e u o u a e.” The section beginning “By him and with him and in him” in the Eucharist Prayer is often described by this term, which is also applied to the “For thine is the kingdom” section of the Lord’s Prayer. When translated into Latin, one of these texts gained the phrase (*) “sicut erat in principio,” or “as it was in the beginning.” In many English-language Protestant traditions, the Offertory ends with one of these texts that’s sung to the tune “Old 100th” and begins “Praise God, from whom all Blessings flow.” The Gloria and the Gloria Patri are the “Greater” and “Lesser” examples of—for 10 points—what short declarations of belief in the Trinity that are typically added to the ends of psalms and hymns?
tossups.answer: doxologies [accept more specific answers like Greater Doxology; prompt on Glorias with “What general kind of prayer are those?”] <Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: doxologies [accept more specific answers like Greater Doxology; prompt on Glorias with “What general kind of prayer are those?”]
acceptable: more specific answers like Greater Doxology
promptable: Glorias with “What general kind of prayer are those?”

tossups.question: Baz’ and Rybachenko proposed a form of this phenomenon that can determine traversal time for particles tunneling across a barrier. Pugh and Schiff name a form of this phenomenon caused due to changes in the metric near the Earth’s poles, which is a special case of a form named for two Austrian scientists that’s been measured by the LAGEOS satellites. This phenomenon accounts for a relativistic correction factor of (*) one-half in the largest term in the fine structure correction to the hydrogen atom. Gravity Probe B measured frame dragging, which causes its Lense–Thirring form. One form of this kind of motion is a Wigner rotation caused by successive boosts and is named for Llewllyn Thomas. The path traced out by this motion is typically not a perfect circle due to nutation. For 10 points, name this motion of a rotation axis exemplified by gyroscopes and tops.
tossups.answer: precession [accept word forms like precessing; accept Pugh–Schiff precession; accept Lense–Thirring precession; accept Larmor precession; accept Thomas precession; prompt on frame dragging before mentioned by asking “Which causes what sort of motion?”] <Science - Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: precession [accept word forms like precessing; accept Pugh–Schiff precession; accept Lense–Thirring precession; accept Larmor precession; accept Thomas precession; prompt on frame dragging before mentioned by asking “Which causes what sort of motion?”]

tossups.question: William Colenso discovered a notable instance of an “out-of-place-artifact” after finding one of these objects with Pandya-era script being used as a potato boiler by Māori women in 1836. Shō Taikyū of the Ryukyu Kingdom commissioned one of these objects known as the “Bridge of Nations.” Portuguese brigand Filipe de Brito supposedly pilfered one of these objects before very stupidly losing it in the Bago River, where it has yet to be recovered. For its role in the 1771 Moscow Plague riot, one of these objects was put on trial, found guilty, and mutilated at the orders of Catherine the Great. Burmese monarch (*) Dhammazedi commissioned the supposedly largest-ever example of these objects for the Shwedagon Pagoda. Paulinus of Nola is credited with introducing these items to Christian worship. During the siege of Belgrade, Callixtus III ordered these objects be used every day at noon to generate prayer. For 10 points, name these large instruments that may be found as part of carillons inside a campanile, their namesake “tower.”
tossups.answer: bells <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: In a film from this country, a character mimes eating a tangerine and then explains that the Kalahari bushmen categorize people into those who feel greater hunger and lesser hunger. In that film from this country, a character smokes pot, takes off her top, and dances to Miles Davis’s “Generique” in front of a sunset. A film from this country begins with a father and children searching for Wi-Fi to steal while their mother folds pizza boxes. The protagonist of a film from this country reads a book of (*) Faulkner stories in a nod to the source of the Haruki Murakami work it adapts. The protagonist of that film from this country is shocked when his love interest returns from trip to Kenya with a rich, older boyfriend, who admits to a hobby of greenhouse arson. The 2019 Palme d’Or winner Parasite and the 2018 mystery drama Burning are from—for 10 points—what country home to Bong Joon-ho and Lee Chang-dong?
tossups.answer: South Korea [or Hanguk; or Republic of Korea or Daehan Minguk; do not accept or prompt on “North Korea” or “Democratic People’s Republic of Korea” or “Choson Minjujuui Inmin Konghwaguk”] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: South Korea [or Hanguk; or Republic of Korea or Daehan Minguk; do not accept or prompt on "“North Korea”" or "“Democratic People’s Republic of Korea”" or "“Choson Minjujuui Inmin Konghwaguk”"]

tossups.question: Marie Gottschalk has written about the “state” created by these institutions in modern America. Michael Conahan and Mark Ciaverella were charged with racketeering conspiracy in a horrendous scandal in the Wilkes–Barre area centering around children and these institutions. It’s not schools, but a 2018 strike was led by people in these institutions after a deadly incident at one of them in Lee County, South Carolina. Operation Mississippi Hustle has investigated Chris Epps for deals made with MTC and GEO, two of the largest (*) owners of these institutions, which were at the center of the Kids-for-Cash scandal. Angela Davis asked Are [these institutions] Obsolete? in a book calling for their abolition. The U.S. contributes 22% of the global population of these institutions, the highest rate in the world. Michelle Alexander’s The New Jim Crow examines—for 10 points—what institutions that receive a so-called “pipeline” from underfunded schools and include Sing Sing and San Quentin?
tossups.answer: prisons [accept jails; accept any equivale answers including jails, penal institutions, penitentiaries, etc.; accept specific examples like private prisons] <Modern World>
tossups.answer_formatted: prisons [accept jails; accept any equivale answers including jails, penal institutions, penitentiaries, etc.; accept specific examples like private prisons]
acceptable: any equivale answers including jails, penal institutions, penitentiaries, etc.

tossups.question: In this play’s final scene, a man who claims that “there is no more miserable creature on the planet than the Smiling Ironic Observer” repeatedly tells a boy to trust him and go eat dinner. The bumbling Reverend Baldbelly appears in this play, in which a character recounts a dream about “legs in sky-blue tights climbing over a podium.” At this play’s premiere, its author played a mysterious Masked Man comforting a boy who had earlier been sent to a (*) reformatory. The Priapus Club is frequented by Ilse in this play, which features a character who masturbates to a reproduction of Vecchio’s Venus. During this play, Hänschen and Ernst fall in love, and the motif of a “headless queen” foreshadows Moritz’s suicide. At the end of this play, a failed abortion kills Wendla, who had been raped by the atheist schoolboy Melchior. For 10 points, name this Frank Wedekind play about the oppression of teenage sexuality.
tossups.answer: Spring Awakening [or Frühlings Erwachen] <Literature - Other/World>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by COincelPRO (Tracy Mirkin, Taylor Harvey, Alex Shaw, Jonathen Settle) and I Cannot Fucking Wait Until Morris Dance Dies (Mike Etzkorn, Matt Lafer, Mitch McCullar, Ryan Westbrook)  Bonuses
tossups.metadata: Tracy Mirkin, Taylor Harvey, Alex Shaw, Jonathen Settle

bonuses.leadin: Richard Gregory, who famously described this process as “hypothesis,” founded a psychology journal titled for it. For 10 points each:
answers: visual perception [or “Perception as Hypothesis” or The Perception of the Visual World; prompt on seeing]
parts: Name this process. In a 1950 book titled for this process, J.J. Gibson emphasized the role of “arrays” and “flows” in his “bottom-up” approach to understanding this process.
This psychological school of thought advanced by Max Wertheimer and Kurt Koffka argued that humans perceive patterns through a set of six “laws of grouping.”
According to this psychologist’s “feature integration theory,” humans perceive objects through two distinct “pre-attentive” and “focused attention” stages.
answers_formatted: visual perception [or “Perception as Hypothesis” or The Perception of the Visual World; prompt on seeing]
acceptable: The Perception of the Visual World

bonuses.leadin: This opera originated as a Viennese-style operetta, leading to its rejection by a publisher as “bad Léhar.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this opera that’s almost exclusively remembered for the aria “Che il bel sogno” [keel bell SOH-nyoh] from its opening party scene.

“Che il bel sogno” begins with a solo by this instrument, which also accompanies the opening of “Großmächtige Prinzessin” [grohss-MEKH-tih-guh PRIN-tzeh-sin] from Ariadne auf Naxos. This instrument is played by a répétiteur.

The opening of “Che il bel sogno” prominently features the Lydian example of these pitch collections, one set of which can be created by starting a diatonic scale in the middle and ending on the same note.

bonuses.leadin: In a section of this book, Danny is embarrassed by being associated with his cousin Chin-Kee. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book by Gene Luen Yang, which interconnects the stories of Danny, Sūn Wùkōng, and the student Jin Wang.
American Born Chinese is a contemporary example of this type of novel told using illustrations. Other contemporary ones include Alison Bechdel’s Fun Home and Marjane Satrapi’s Persepolis.

This author is often called the “father of the graphic novel” for his 1978 book A Contract with God. He discussed ways to tell stories visually in his books Comics and Visual Art and Graphic Storytelling and Visual Narrative.

bonuses.leadin: Manuela Gandarillas, an elderly blind woman from this city, led a mob of women with saucepans and kitchen knives in an inspirational revolt against Spanish forces, who immediately killed them. For 10 points each:
answers: Cochabamba [or Quchapampa or Quchapanpa; prompt on “La Llajta”]
Plurinational State of Bolivia [or Mborivia; or Puliwya]
parts: Name this city wracked with protests over a spike in water prices after mayor Manfred Reyes Villa tried to force the foreign-owned consortium Aguas del Tunari to build a dam via the unethical Law 2029.

The Cochabamba Water War contributed to the political unrest that’s prevailed in this South American country in recent years. Aymara president Evo Morales has promoted this country’s coca-based economy.

This dictator of Bolivia for most of the 1970s somehow got himself elected as a constitutional president with the ADN party. This prolific torturer had a long feud with Juan Lechín of the powerful Bolivian Workers Center union.

bonuses.leadin: Arthur Rosenfeld was likely the first person to formulate this standard by calculating the number of potential resonances as the total number of histograms times the number of deceptive fluctuations per histogram. For 10 points each:
answers: 5 sigma standard [accept anything mentioning that the observation must be five standard deviations away from the mean]
neutrinos [accept electron neutrinos; accept mu neutrinos; accept tau neutrinos; prompt on fermions] <Science - Physics>
parts: Name this standard used in particle physics that dictates how unlikely a fluctuation must be for it to be considered significant. A descrription is fine.

This fake discovery by a team at Fermilab probably wouldn’t have been published if the 5 sigma rule was used. This “punning-ly” named “particle” was reported as a 6 G·e·V resonance that produced electron-positron pairs.

Adhering to the 5 sigma rule might also have prevented the rabbit hole that particle physics went down looking for a 17 k·e·V one of these particles reported by John Simpson in 1985. Evidence for their oscillations was reported by Super-Kamiokande, SNO, and KamLAND.
answers_formatted: 5 sigma standard [accept anything mentioning that the observation must be five standard deviations away from the mean]
neutrinos [accept electron neutrinos; accept mu neutrinos; accept tau neutrinos; prompt on fermions]
acceptable: anything mentioning that the observation must be five standard deviations away from the mean

bonuses.leadin: In Honoré d’Urfé’s novel L’Astrée, unicorns and lions guard one of these places “of love’s truth.” For 10 points each:
answers: The Romance of the Rose [or Le Roman de la Rose]
parts: Name these places often used to symbolize love or desire in medieval romances. The title character of Chrétien de Troyes’ Yvain slays Esclados de Roux, who guards one of these places that magically produces storms.
Characters fall in love at the fountain of Narcissus in this thirteenth-century French allegory, which was begun by Guillaume de Loris and continued by Jean de Meun.

In a long twelfth-century French poem, this figure visits three miraculous fountains near India. Walter of Chatillon wrote an extremely popular medieval Latin version of this legendary figure’s namesake “romance.”
answers_formatted: The Romance of the Rose [or Le Roman de la Rose]

bonuses.leadin: This set of prayers follows the Japji and the So Dar as the final part of the Adi Granth Sahib’s pre-raga introductory section. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this set of hymns recited by Sikhs at bedtime, after the evening recitation of the Rehras.
Another bedtime prayer is this excerpt from Deuteronomy that observant Jews also recite upon waking up and as their last words.

Upon waking up and going to bed, Jains often recite the Namōkāra mantra, which consists of bowing to this number of groups of holy figures. Jain ethics centers on this number of “vows,” including ahimsa.

bonuses.leadin: Frank McEwen helped establish a Workshop School for artists in this modern-day country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this modern country where Roy Guthrie helped establish Chapungu Sculpture Park to showcase the work artists like Joram Mariga and Bernard Takawira. Its flag depicts an 15th-century sculpture in the white triangle on the left side.
This is the dominant material in Shona sculpture. This kind of stone was used for the 15th-century bird sculptures at Great Zimbabwe.

These figurines from Sierra Leone and some western parts of Liberia are typically carved out of soapstone or steatite. The Mende and Kisi people make offerings to these bulging-eyed sculptures for safety and a good harvest.

bonuses.leadin: The Hodge star gives a duality between vector spaces defined using this operation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this antisymmetric operation that’s used to define differential forms.
The norm of the wedge product of a collection of vectors can be given as the square root of this matrix’s determinant. Given a matrix A, this matrix can be written as “A-transpose times A.”

Thus, in three dimensions, the Gramian determinant gives you the square of the volume of one of these figures formed by the vectors. The determinant of a 3-by-3 matrix gives you the volume of one of these figures formed by its columns.

bonuses.leadin: Luca Landucci claimed that a horrifying abomination with a single leg and an eye on its knee, the so-called “monster of” this battle, was born in the month leading up to it. For 10 points each:
answers: War of the League of Cambrai [or the War of the Holy League; prompt on Italian Wars or French invasions of Italy]
Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba (y Enríquez de Aguilar) [or Gonsalvo de Cordova] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Identify this battle where Gaston DeFoix was killed, souring a victory for Louis XII’s forces over a combined Spanish-Papal Army. It is named for a city whose last Byzantine exarch was executed by the Lombards in 751.

The Battle of Ravenna occurred during this war, which saw later clashes at Novara and Marignano. Francis I came to power in France just in time to lose this war, which was named for a group formed by Julius II.

After losing at Seminara, this Spanish general and “Gran Capitan” pioneered the pike and shot tactics that defined tercio warfare during the Italian Wars and for centuries beyond. He crushed the Duke of Nemours at the 1503 Battle of Cerignola.
answers_formatted: War of the League of Cambrai [or the War of the Holy League; prompt on Italian Wars or French invasions of Italy]
acceptable: War of the League of Cambrai

bonuses.leadin: A.A. Long recently translated this philosopher’s Discourses as the book How to Be Free. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Stoic philosopher whose Handbook, compiled by his student Arrian, advocates living “in accordance to nature” and places much weight on the distinction between the prohairetic and the aprohairetic.

The central goal of Epictetus’s ethical teaching was this concept, ofoten translated as “flourishing.” According to the Stoics, this state could be achieved by first achieving ataraxia, apatheia, and eupatheiai.

Epictetus identified two types of “other-concern.” One, translated as “modesty,” is an awareness of the other’s perspective and a willingness to change one’s behavior accordingly; the other is a willingness to act on another's behalf. Give either Greek term.

bonuses.leadin: These groups title a 1927 “informal history” by Herbert Asbury. For 10 points each:
answers: Gangs of New York City [prompt on partial answer; prompt on criminal groups or similar answers with “where were they active?”]
Master Juba [or Boz’s Juba; or William Henry Lane] <History - American>
parts: Name these groups that included the Plug Uglies and Dead Rabbits, whose member Hell-Cat Maggie supposedly filed her teeth into points.

Along with the Bowery, this neighborhood was the major setting for Asbury’s Gangs of New York. This home to the Old Brewery and an infamous prison known as The Tombs was named for the shapes created by Orange and Cross streets.
This black dancer, who combined Irish jig and African dance into a unique style, got his start in the Five Points neighborhood. He would often defeat white dancers like John Diamond in dance battles.
answers_formatted: Gangs of New York City [prompt on partial answer; prompt on criminal groups or similar answers with “where were they active?”]
promptable: similar answers with “where were they active?”

bonuses.leadin: A volume in this series by Jonathan Lethem asks if the title “intermediary artifact” is “paranoid,” “Science Fiction,” or even “Asperger’s.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book series published by Bloomsbury Press, which includes a John Darnielle novella about psychiatric patient Roger Painter, who waxes poetic about Black Sabbath.

Philip Shaw’s 33 ⅓ entry calls this 1975 album “equal parts rock and Rimbaud.” This album includes a version of “Land of a Thousand Dances” in a nine-and-a-half-minute epic about “Johnny,” and its cover photo was taken by Robert Mapplethorpe.
Ezra Furman’s wrote a 33 ⅓ volume on Transformer, the second solo album by this musician who led the Velvet Underground with John Cale. He also released the experimental album Metal Machine Music.

bonuses.leadin: The use of cyanide ions to produce benzoin in a coupling reaction is an example of this process. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process that involves chemically modifying a carbon-heteroatom bond to allow new secondary reactions, where the carbon acts as a nucleophile. Another example of it involves reacting an aldehyde or ketone with a dithiol, deprotonating and reacting with an electrophile, and then deprotecting with mercury(II).

The Stetter reaction is an umpolung that produces 1,4-dicarbonyls using derivatives of this heterocycle as a catalyst. It’s present in vitamin B1, and its active deprotonated form has two contributing resonance structures: an ylide and a carbene.
Thiazole rings have six pi electrons and thus have this property according to Huckel’s rule. Benzene is the prototypical compound with this property.

bonuses.leadin: In 2019, workers in this job began to break their NDAs to speak out against working conditions after Keith Utley’s stress-induced heart attack in Tampa. For 10 points each:
answers: content moderators of Facebook [accept equivalent answers indicating people who work for Facebook by screening user videos, photos, posts, etc; accept Facebook Community Action Team Members from Zuckerbot]
parts: Name this specific job, mainly managed by the contractor Cognizant. A 2016 article by The Verge relayed how individuals in this job had breakdowns and turned to rampant sex in company stairwells after being exposed to videos of stabbings and other extreme acts.

The terrible work conditions and low pay for Facebook contractor employees in Phoenix and Tampa is in stark contrast to the work done at Facebook HQ in this Silicon Valley city, which shares its name with the New Jersey city where Thomas Edison worked.
Facebook moderation standards have also been criticized for overreach, as when a post quoting this eighteenth-century document’s use of the phrase “Indian savages” was deemed hate speech.
answers_formatted: content moderators of Facebook [accept equivalent answers indicating people who work for Facebook by screening user videos, photos, posts, etc; accept Facebook Community Action Team Members from Zuckerbot]
acceptable: equivalent answers indicating people who work for Facebook by screening user videos, photos, posts, etc
Facebook Community Action Team Members from Zuckerbot

bonuses.leadin: The only extant architectural drawing from the early middle ages is housed in and named for this location. For 10 points each:
answers: Abbey of Saint Gall [or Sankt Gallen]
Notker [accept Notker the Stammerer or Notker Balbulus]
parts: Name this religious site in northeast Switzerland, a Benedictine site whose famed Carolingian library contains the aforementioned drawing as well as original manuscripts of the Nibelungenlied.

Strangely, every notable historical person with this name is associated with the Abbey of Saint Gall in some way. The most notable person with this name probably wrote the Gesta Caroli Magni, or deeds of Charlemagne, and had a speech impediment.

Notker Labeo, or Thick-Lipped Notker, is best known for pioneering translations of Boëthius and biblical texts into the Old High dialect of this language, whose dialects included Alemannic and Bavarian.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of this novel realizes that he’s been shipped to fight a fake battle in Ireland so that he can be killed as a means of population control. For 10 points each:
answers: The Children of Men (by P.D. James) <Literature - British>
parts: Name this 1962 novel about government employee Tristram Foxe and his wife Beatrice-Joanna, who becomes pregnant illegally after forgetting to take her government-provided contraceptives.
The dystopian novel The Wanting Seed was written by this British author, who invented slang called Nadsat for a novel about Alex and his gang of violent droogs.

Fertility is also central to this dystopian novel, in which the United Kingdom is ruled by a dictatorial Warden after a sterility crisis during Year Omega. Its narrator, Theo Faron, joins a dissident group called the Five Fishes.

bonuses.leadin: This poem was inspired by an experience its author had driving home with his friend Robert Bly. For 10 points each:
answers: “A Blessing” [or “The Blessing” since it was also published under that title]
parts: Name this poem, whose speaker stops off the highway to admire two grazing “Indian ponies,” making him realize “that if I stepped out of my body I would break into blossom.”

This author of “A Blessing” declared “I have wasted my life” at the end of his poem “Lying in a Hammock at William Duffy’s Farm in Pine Island, Minnesota.” He won the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry 32 years before it was awarded to his son Franz.

In another Wright poem, the speaker observes two of these birds “exchanging their prey.” Robinson Jeffers claimed that he would sooner kill a man than one of these birds in a poem whose speaker fails to nurse a hurt one back to health.
answers_formatted: “A Blessing” [or “The Blessing” since it was also published under that title]

bonuses.leadin: This genus appears in the fossil record in the middle of the Silurian and disappears in the early Devonian. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genus of transitional land plant that had a simple stalk with a few branchings, ending with a sporangium. They lacked leaves, flowers, and roots and are described as “trumpet-shaped.”
Cooksonia species are transitional between modern vascular land plants and this paraphyletic group of plants, which contains the hornworts, liverworts, and mosses.
This stage of the bryophyte life cycle is the sexual stage and the dominant one. Archegonia and antheridia are produced on this stage.

bonuses.leadin: For a 2019 New Yorker profile, this musician shared her research on Frank Johnson, one of the many black forefathers of modern “white” genres like bluegrass and string band music. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this musician who, after graduating from Oberlin with a degree in opera performance, took up the fiddle and founded the Carolina Chocolate Drops.
In 2017, Giddens became one of the rare musicians to perform at both this Rhode Island city’s annual Folk Festival and its Jazz Festival.

On her 2019 album There Is no Other, Giddens was accompanied by percussionist Francesco Turrisi on this kind of hand-held drum. This is the generic term for drums like tambourines that are wider than they are deep.
